content.raw:
I'm not sure why. It looks like the gap is ~0.016 m, in that if I shift a tile by 0.016, it closes the gap. I thought it might be related to the scale parameter passed to `tile_tsv.py`, but looking at tunnel world in gazebo9 branch, the tunnel world was generated with the default scaling \(--scale\_x 20 --scale\_y 20\), which is the same for the urban world.  
Maybe it has to do with the actual scaling of the meshes? I did notice that the tiles might be twice as large as the tunnel tiles, because the tiles had to be specified every other cell in the `.tsv` file in order to not overlap 50% in the generated `.sdf`.  
I tried setting the scale to 10, but that made the tiles overlap a lot that the world is unusable.  
I also tried removing the every other empty row and column, to see if the empty rows and columns were the cause of the gaps, and scaled to 40. The gaps persisted. So it might be the meshes?
content.html:
I'm not sure why. It looks like the gap is ~0.016 m, in that if I shift a tile by 0.016, it closes the gap. I thought it might be related to the scale parameter passed to tile_tsv.py, but looking at tunnel world in gazebo9 branch, the tunnel world was generated with the default scaling (--scale_x 20 --scale_y 20), which is the same for the urban world.
Maybe it has to do with the actual scaling of the meshes? I did notice that the tiles might be twice as large as the tunnel tiles, because the tiles had to be specified every other cell in the .tsv file in order to not overlap 50% in the generated .sdf.
I tried setting the scale to 10, but that made the tiles overlap a lot that the world is unusable.
I also tried removing the every other empty row and column, to see if the empty rows and columns were the cause of the gaps, and scaled to 40. The gaps persisted. So it might be the meshes?
